When the 'Kunai-sho Kansei' (Imperial Household Ministry Organization) (Article 3 of Koshitsu-rei; the Imperial Families' Act, in 1907) was established, it was under the control of Shikibu-shoku of Imperial Household Agency as 'tenshiki.'

The Shoten-bu was placed under the Shikibu-shoku, and it was decided that this section should consist of a position called shoten-cho (the chief ritualist), a position called shoten-jicho (the vice-chief ritualist), shoten (regular ritualists), nai-shoten (female regular ritualists), and shoten-ho (assistant staff).

sen.j: 「掌典長」は親任官又は勅任官とされ、皇室祭祀に奉仕し、掌典部・掌典職の事務を掌理し、所部職員を監督する。
sen.e: `Ceremony Department Manager' corresponds to an official appointed by the emperor or an imperial appointee, and he/she engages in the services of court rituals, controls administration of ceremony staff and ceremony department, and supervise the staff of Ceremony Department.

`Ceremony Department Manager' corresponds to an official appointed by the emperor or an imperial appointee, and he/she engages in the services of court rituals, controls administration of ceremony staff and ceremony department, and supervises the staff of Ceremony Department.

The 'shoten-cho' should be an official personally or directly appointed by the Emperor, and his duties are to serve for Court rituals, to manage tasks of the department and the staff, and to supervise all members in the department.

sen.j: 「掌典次長」は勅任官とされ、掌典長をたすけ、掌典長に事故があるときはその職務を代理する。
sen.e: `Ceremony Department Deputy Manager' is an imperial appointee, and he/she supports Ceremony Department Manager; he/she acts for the manager when the manager is not available.
`Ceremony Department Deputy Manager' is an imperial appointee, and he/she supports Ceremony Department Manager; he/she acts for the manager when the manager is not available.
The 'shoten-jicho' should be an official directly appointed by the Emperor, and his duties are to support the shoten-cho and to take over his responsibility when he is not available.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 「掌典」は12人を定員とされ、奏任官（名誉職とすることもできた。）とし、祭事を分掌する。
sen.e: The number of `Staff' is limited to 12, and the duties of the staff are segregated to perform services; he/she is an official who is originally selected as a candidates by the Prime Minister (can be regarded as honorable position).

Shoten' staff consists of 12 members who are officials appointed with the Emperor's approval (such officials were called soninkan, and the position of soninkan was sometimes given as an honorary post), and they take partial charge of Court rituals.

sen.j: 「掌典職官制」（昭和14年皇室令第4号）により、宮内省に掌典職が置かれ、掌典職には、掌典長、掌典次長、掌典、内掌典、掌典補、事務官及び属を置くことが定められた。
sen.e: `Ceremonial Staff Organization' (Article 4 of Koshitsu-rei; the Imperial Families' Act, in 1939) specified Imperial Household Ministry set the ceremonial staff under which Manager, Deputy Manager, Staff, Junior staff, Assistant, Administrator and Attendant are placed in Imperial Household Ministry.
sen.cmt: 属の訳出が不明ですが暫定的に attendant としています。掌典職官制に関 しても訳出が不明ですが暫定的に Ceremonial staff organization と訳出しています。
sen.e: `Ceremonial Staff Organization' (Article 4 of Koshitsu-rei; the Imperial Families' Act, in 1939) specified Imperial Household Ministry set the ceremonial staff under which Manager, Deputy Manager, Staff, Junior staff, Assistant, Administrator and Attendant are placed in the Imperial Household Ministry.

In accordance with the 'Shoten-shoku Kansei' (the regulations for the organization of the shoten-shoku), which was announced in the Imperial Household Order No. 4 of 1939, the Ministry of Imperial Household established a department called Shoten-shoku, and they also decided to place the positions in this department as follows: the shoten-cho, the shoten-jicho, shoten, nai-shoten, shoten-ho, administrative officials, and minor officials.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 掌典長、掌典次長、掌典、内掌典及び掌典補は、宮内省式部職掌典部時代と同様の職掌である。
sen.e: The duties of Manager, Deputy Manager, Staff, Junior staff, Assistant are similar to the duties of Ceremony department in Board of Ceremonies of Imperial Household Ministry.
The duties of Manager, Deputy Manager, Staff, Junior staff, Assistant are similar to the duties of the Ceremony department in the Board of Ceremonies of the Imperial Household Ministry.
The duties of the shoten-cho, the shoten-jicho, shoten, nai-shoten, and shoten-ho were respectively the same as the ones which had been decided when the previous organization had been established.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 「事務官」は奏任官として掌典職の庶務を掌り、「属」は判任官として掌典職の庶務に従事していた。
sen.e: `Administrator' took charge of general affairs of ceremonial staff as an official who is originally selected as a candidates by the Prime Minister, and `Attendant' was engaged in general affairs of ceremonial staff as a Junior official.

`Administrator' takes charge of general affairs of the ceremonial staff as an official who is originally selected as a candidate by the Prime Minister, and the `Attendant' was engaged in the general affairs of the ceremonial staff as a Junior official.

Administrative officials, who were at the position of soninkan, were responsible for general affairs in this department, and they were supported by minor officials, who were at the position of hanninkan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 1947年（昭和22年）5月3日の日本国憲法施行に伴う同省の廃止（宮内府への移行）により、掌典職も国家機関としては廃止された。
sen.e: The ceremonial staff was abolished by the reason of the abolishment of Imperial Household Ministry (shift to Kunaifu; Imperial Household agency) due to enforcement of the Constitution of Japan on May 3, 1947.
The ceremonial staff of the Imperial Household Ministry (shift for the Kunaifu; Imperial Household agency) due to enforcement of the Constitution of Japan on May 3, 1947.

The Shoten-shoku as a governmental organization was abolished due to the abolishment of the Ministry of Imperial Household (this Ministry was demoted to the Imperial Household Office) in accordance with the enforcement of the Constitution of Japan on May 3, 1947.
